Problem:
Consider a function defined as \\( f(z) = \\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{izt} g(t) dt \\) where \\( g(t) \\) represents a function of time. This scenario deals with the Fourier transform of \\( g(t) \\) and explores what happens as this transformation is applied to different functional forms of \\( g(t) \\).

If \\( g(t) \\) is a sine function, without any intervention, will the output of \\( f(z) \\) retain the sinusoidal nature of \\( g(t) \\)?
Explanation: The Fourier transform of a sine function results in Dirac delta functions at specific frequencies corresponding to the sine wave, thus transforming the time-domain sinusoidal nature into a frequency-domain representation. This significantly alters the nature from sinusoidal to spiky.
